questions.text: A 43-year-old multigravida presents with nausea, vomiting, fever, and rightupper quadrant pain. On examination, she displays arrested inspiration on palpation of the right upper quadrant. Her laboratory results reveal neutrophilia with a "left shift." Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS:
    • This patient presents with the classic signs of cholecystitis, or inflammation of the gallbladder wall, which is usually due to obstruction of the cystic duct by gallstones.
    • Gross findings:- enlarged and distended gallbladder, occasionally hemorrhagic external surface. Thickened
    • 3 types:-
      • Calculous
      • Acalculous
      • Emphysematous.
  • Cholangiocarcinoma (choice D) is a malignancy of the bile ducts.
  • Cholesterolosis, (choice C) also known as strawberry gallbladder, is noninflammatory in nature.
  • Sclerosing cholangitis (choice A) is an inflammatory condition of the extrahepatic bile ducts that is often associated with chronic ulcerative colitis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Cholecystitis, or inflammation of the gallbladder wall, which is usually due to obstruction of the cystic duct by gallstones.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Crigler - najjar syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hepatic Jaundice

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:-

  1. DEFECTIVE UPTAKE OF BILIRUBIN BY LIVER CELLS FROM BLOOD: (choice A)
    • GILBERT’S SYNDROME
      • The most common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia,
      • Autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
      • mild deficiency of glucuronyl transferase.
      • Jaundice becomes noticeable during illness or after fasting. Mildly elevated serum bilirubin is the sole abnormality; other LFTs are normal.
  2. Defective conjugation of bilirubin: (choice B)
    • CRIGLER-NAJJAR SYNDROME: two types.
      • Type I : Autosomal recessive mode of inheritance, complete absence of glucuronyl transferase, severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and kernicterus (deposition of bilirubin in basal ganglia of brain).
      • Type II : less severe disease.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia:

  • HEPATOCELLULAR DISEASE:
    • Liver enzymes raised (ALT & AST)
    • In hepatocellular injury, both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin are increased.
    • Unconjugated bilirubin is increased due to reduced ability of liver cells to conjugate bilirubin.
    • Conjugated bilirubin is raised from cholestasis due to hepatocyte swelling.
  • INTRAHEPATIC CHOLESTASIS:
    1. Impairment of secretion of bilirubin from hepatocytes into the biliary canaliculi
    2. Obstruction of bile flow in canaliculi by swollen hepatocytes; or
    3. Damage to intrahepatic canaliculi.
  • DUBIN-JOHNSON SYNDROME (choice D)
    • Defect in the excretion of bilirubin by hepatocytes
    • Liver is darkly pigmented due to accumulation of polymerized epinephrine metabolites.
    • Bromo sulphthalein excretion test is abnormal
  • ROTOR SYNDROME (choice C)
    • Impaired excretion of bilirubin but without pigmentation of liver;
    • Bromosulphthalein test is normal.
    • Alkaline phosphatase is normal in both conditions.
  • DRUGS
    • Oral contraceptives
    • Anabolic steroids
    • Oral anti-diabetics
    • Phenothiazines
  • PRIMARY BILIARY CIRRHOSIS
    • Autoimmune destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts

KEY TAKEAWAYS: CRIGLER-NAJJAR SYNDROME: two types.

Type I : Autosomal recessive mode of inheritance, complete absence of glucuronyl transferase, severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and kernicterus (deposition of bilirubin in basal ganglia of brain).

Type II : less severe disease.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents to his family physician for a routine physical prior to moving away for college. Other than feeling slightly stressed by new life situation, she has no complaints. A comprehensive metabolic panel reveals a modestly elevated unconjugated bilirubin but a near-normal aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase. It is likely that the patient may have which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• GILBERT SYNDROME: defective uptake of bilirubin by liver cells from blood (choice C)
    • an extremely common cause of clinically insignificant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
    • The hyperbilirubinemia is episodic, with increases related to stress, fatigue, alcohol use, or recurrent infection.
    • Autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
    • Mild deficiency of glucuronyl transferase.
    • Jaundice becomes noticeable during illness or after fasting. Mildly elevated serum bilirubin is the sole abnormality; other LFTs are normal.
  • CRIGLER-NAJJAR SYNDROME I (choice A) is often lethal, although CRIGLER-NAJJAR SYNDROME II is compatible with life and often presents with extreme jaundice and neurologic defects secondary to kernicterus.
  • DUBIN JOHNSON SYNDROME and ROTOR SYNDROME cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. (Choice B & D)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A benign hereditary condition characterized by intermittent mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme uridine diphosphate-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1).

questions.text: A 55-year-old alcoholic man died after an illness characterized by increasing jaundice, ascites, and generalized wasting. Lab tests revealed hyperbilirubinemia, hypoalbuminemia, and mildly elevated liver enzymes. The appearance of the liver at autopsy is shown in the figure. What could be the possible diagnosis from the following?
questions.solution:
• The above figure demonstrates the typical appearance of micronodular cirrhosis, the most common cause of which is alcoholism.
    • Major clinical manifestations include jaundice, ascites, signs of hyperestrogenism (palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy)
      • Consequences of increased portal venous pressure (esophageal varices, Distended abdominal veins [caput medusae], splenomegaly)
      • Consequences of hypoalbuminemia (ascites, peripheral edema).
      • Laboratory findings :-
        • Elevated serum aminotransferases,
        • hyperbilirubinemia,
        • variable elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase,
        • hypoproteinemia (globulins, albumin, and clotting factors), and 
        • anemia
    • Cirrhosis may be clinically silent, discovered only at autopsy or when a stress such as infection or trauma tips the balance toward hepatic insufficiency.

Key Takeaways: The most common cause of micronodular cirrhosis is alcohol.

questions.text: A middle aged alcoholic man having complaints of weight loss, upper abdominal discomfort, malaise and anorexia since last two weeks. On clinical examination, hepatomegaly is noticed. On CBC, there was neutrophilic leukocytosis. Laboratory tests reveals increased serum aminotransferases, serum alkaline phosphatase and serum bilirubin. The liver specimen shows the following morphological features. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ALCOHOLIC HEPATITIS:- Arrows indicate MALLORY BODIES (alcoholic hyalin). destructive changes of hepatocytes

  • Fatty change (not shown here), and a neutrophilic inflammatory infiltrate are other characteristics include fatty change, focal liver cell necrosis, infiltrates of neutrophils, and the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic hyaline inclusions (Mallory bodies) derived from cytokeratin intermediate filaments; these inclusions are characteristic, but not entirely specific for alcoholic hepatitis.
  • irreversible fibrosis that characteristically surrounds central veins and has been referred to as perivenular fibrosis, sclerosing hyaline necrosis, or central hyaline sclerosis.
  • This fibrosis can lead to central vein obstruction and fibrosis surrounding individual liver cells and can result in cirrhosis.
  • All the clinical findings suggest towards the diagnosis of alcoholic hepatitis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Acute inflammation and injury to the liver caused by excessive alcohol consumption, often seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

Reference: https://medchrome.com/basic-science/pathology/morphology-alcoholic-liver-disease/

questions.text: When comparing alcohol-related steatohepatitis with non-alcohol-related steatohepatitis, all of the following is TRUE, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
SATELLITOSIS IS MORE COMMON IN ALCOHOLIC STEATOHEPATITIS.

  • Sclerosing hyaline necrosis is characterized by extensive hepatocyte necrosis in a perivenular pattern with associated fibrous deposition. This can occlude the terminal hepatic venules leading to portal hypertension (in the absence of cirrhosis). (Choice d)
  • Mallory-Denk bodies are typically more plentiful in alcohol related steatohepatitis and remain even after the disappearance of fatty changes. (Choice B)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Satellitosis is the ringing of neutrophils around Mallory-Denk body containing hepatocytes and is more often seen in alcohol-related liver disease.

questions.text: A 17-year-old was brought to the emergency room by his parents with symptoms of frank psychosis. His drugs of abuse screen was negative and his metabolic panel was normal expect for mildly elevated transaminases. A liver biopsy (A- H&E stain, B- Rhodamine stain) was performed and is shown below. Which of the following is the BEST diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history and biopsy results are consistent with WILSON DISEASE.

  • Wilson disease results from tissue injury by copper overload in the liver and other organs (brain, cornea, and kidneys).
  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • The gene mutation of which is localized on chromosome 13q14-21.
  • Copper deposition in the hepatocytes is complex, with several factors involved besides the Wilson ATPase, including copper transporters, metallochaperones, and metallothionein.
  • Homozygous subjects have increased copper levels in the liver at a very young age, but symptoms of liver disease do not typically develop before the age of 5 years.
  • Neuropsychiatric symptoms:- Depression to frank psychosis and often with Parkinsonlike movement disorders.
  • The first presentation can be fulminant hepatic failure.
  • The microscopic findings:-
    • Mild periportal inflammatory infiltrate along with glycogenation of periportal hepatocytes. Often patients will present with
    • macro or microvesicular steatosis and
    • the presence of Mallory hyaline.
    • Image B shows patchy copper staining in rhodamine stain.
  • Vitamin A overdose would result in hypertrophy of hepatic stellate cells and resulting sinusoidal dilation and peliosis. (Choice D)
  • Tricyclic antidepressants cause hepatic damage, they demonstrate a pattern of cholestatic hepatitis but can also demonstrate spotty, submassive, or massive necrosis.(choice C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: An autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective copper metabolism leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, cornea, and other tissues due to mutations in the ATP7B gene.

Mnemonic: "WILSON" for Wilson Disease

  • W: Worldwide autosomal recessive disorder.
  • I: Impaired ATP7B function.
  • L: Liver involvement (hepatitis, cirrhosis).
  • S: Slit-lamp for Kayser-Fleischer rings.
  • O: Organ deposits (brain, cornea, kidney).
  • N: Neurological and psychiatric symptoms.

questions.text: Choose the correct option from the following about focal nodular hyperplasia of liver.
questions.solution:
FOCAL NODULAR HYPERPLASIA

  • Benign, non-neoplastic lesion
  • Most common in adult women
  • Pathogenesis:- Altered blood flow that leads to hyperplastic changes in hepatocytes.
  • FNH-like nodules can occur adjacent to hemangiomas and Budd-Chiari syndrome. Multifocal FNH can occur in association with hepatic or extrahepatic hemangioma, vascular malformations, meningioma and astrocytoma
  • MORPHOLOGY:-
    • Well circumscribed, typically lacks a capsule, and has
    • A central stellate scar.
    • Size of the lesion- 5 cm or less in diameter.
    • Microscopically, fibrous septa radiate from the central scar dividing the hepatic parenchyma into The fibrous septa and central scar contain thick-walled arteries with intimal and fibromuscular hyperplasia and poorly formed elastic lamina.
    • A prominent ductular reaction is often present, but interlobular bile ducts are absent. The hepatocytes in the nodules are arranged in one- to two cell-thick plates; cytologic and architectural atypia is not present.
    • IHC:- Glutamine synthetase (GS), an enzyme normally present in centrizonal hepatocytes, is very useful for diagnosis. In FNH, a highly characteristic "maplike pattern" of strong cytoplasmic GS staining is seen within anastomosing groups of hepatocytes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A benign hepatic lesion characterized by a hyperplastic response of hepatocytes to a vascular anomaly.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focal_nodular_hyperplasia

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with chronic right upper quadrant pain. A routine laparoscopic cholecystostomy was performed, and representative sections are shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the above lesion is FALSE?
questions.solution:
The above lesion demonstrates a GALLBLADDER CARCINOMA.

  • The majority of patients are diagnosed at an advanced, surgically unresectable, stage.
  • The mean 5-year survival rate for affected patients is less than 10%.
  • These lesions are inoperable in approximately 50% of cases at the time of diagnosis. (Choice A)
  • Approximately 80% of these lesions demonstrate extension into the liver, and 50%-80% demonstrate lymph node metastasis.
  • Pathogenesis:- The K-ras codon 12 mutation as well as mutations in the APC gene, amplification of the c-erb-2 gene, and increased expression of the p53 protein have all been described. (Choice D)
  • Most patients have advanced disease at diagnosis, and the overall prognosis for such patients is poor, even with apparently complete resection of evident tumor.
  • Adjuvant chemotherapy is often offered to such patients but is not curative, and most patients eventually succumb to their disease.(choice C)
  • Gallbladder carcinoma has a great propensity to invade the liver directly, and to less extent the stomach and duodenum; it also metastasizes frequently to liver (often through the portal tracts), cystic and pericholedochal lymph nodes in the lesser omentum, and lymph nodes behind the first portion of the duodenum. The frequency of lymph node involvement is highly dependent on the depth of invasion of the primary tumor. (Choice B)
